Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Personal Models for a Navigational Approach to Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific and technological advances in the last century have helped humankind move past infectious disease as the primary cause of mortality. Average lifespan has doubled from 40 years to above 80 years in developed countries. Today, chronic disease presents our greatest health challenge. Current healthcare practice based on the episodic infectious disease health model is not a good approach to treating chronic disease. Instead, healthcare needs to focus on diet, exercise, and other lifestyle activities. Future health systems will use rich, multi-modal data to sense health state continuously and provide guidance in making daily lifestyle decisions. The lifestyle navigational approach is a close-loop sense-estimate-act cycle based on sensors, computing elements, and actuators and closely guided by the personal model of the individual. To provide guidance, predict the future, or understand preferences of an individual, we must build a model that is specific to an individual. The personal model contains not only ordinary medical record data, but also information about disease propensity and lifestyle behaviors.

This project will develop methods to easily and accurately track behaviors that have an impact on health and chronic disease, and methods for incorporating such information into a personalized lifestyle health model. These models will be critical in developing a navigational approach to health in order to facilitate precision medicine based on predictive and preventive approaches. Nutrition is one of the major components of lifestyle, and yet there are no fully satisfactory approaches for food logging. This proposal will specifically create a novel approach to food logging based on using a wearable sensor to detect heart rate changes associated with eating, which triggers an ecological momentary assessment (EMA) for food logging. A food log compared with already available activity logs provides enough quantitative information to understand and analyze lifestyle quantitatively for a person. This project will develop novel event mining techniques by extending machine learning approaches for building lifestyle related causal models for a person that will be used in predictive approaches as well as in guiding the person's lifestyle decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quality of life for every human primarily depends on their health state.  Health is the most essential ingredient to achieve any life goal. Until the last century, technology and resources influenced people to think about health as the absence of diseases. This century brought resources and technology to quantify lifestyle and individual health state. Moreover, smartphones, wearables, and an emerging plethora of sensors now allow continuous measurement of biological, emotional, social, and environmental parameters for a person. This rich personal data facilitates considering each individual as a unique person, rather than as a sample of a population. Many health and medicine related thought leaders see the potential of using this information to revolutionize health. We are thus entering the stage where caring for your health will not mean eliminating disease, but rather achieving the health state that enables the best quality of life an individual aspires to.  This EAGER proposal provided for early investigations in this pursuit through the idea of health navigation.


We developed the concept of a Personal Health Navigator, a system that uses a personal model tied to perpetual closed-loop homeostatic control to continuously observe the health state of an individual and provide guidance in selecting the best lifestyle and medical choices. Inspiration for this method arises from the ubiquitous use of modern geographic navigational systems that helps a user reach their desired destination. These systems work through combining complex layers of dynamic domain knowledge (such as map layers), precise determination of state (such as GPS), and perpetual planning (such as routing algorithms). We investigated these computing principles applied to a person in the real dynamic world to guide them continuously by providing the right information at the right time, in a relevant context, to get to their destination. We want to empower people by developing a personal health navigator to accomplish their health goals that underlie the quality of life they desire.  


In this EAGER proposal, we addressed two critical issues related to building personal models. The first is the challenge of building Personicles, and the second is determining the health state. For making the Personicle, we refined our earlier work on creating logs of personal daily activities by addressing a challenging problem of logging all food items ingested by a person. We explored the relationship between heart rate increase and food for adequate food diary preparation. Such a food diary is essential to understand the nutrition profile of a person as well as understanding how this person's body reacts to specific foods or their combinations. This is essential to understand what to recommend to the person. Since personal chronicle, or Personicle, is very important to log all activities and measurements related to a person for applying powerful techniques from machine learning and AI to build a personal model, we developed software to record all this information. We made this software, called Personicle, open source so researchers can build upon it.


For determining the health state, we investigated how to characterize personalized cardiac health state using commonly used sensors. Hospitals use many techniques to assess this with expensive and invasive equipment. However, estimation of the cardiac health state of a person based on commonly available lifestyle sensors has not been studied in depth. We started developing techniques to do this using dynamic graph network blocks.


Based on our results and accepted publications, these approaches suggest the feasibility of the navigational approach presented in our vision paper that represents the general concepts behind this research funding.
